Hike these 'coffin roads' for an unmatched view of Scotland
entry.summary:
Coffin roads were used throughout the Scottish Highlands and Islands to carry caskets on foot to cemeteries with burial rites. In the Highlands and Islands, trace the steps of historic funeral processions through epic landscapes on some of Scotland‚Äôs most intriguing hikes.
Across abandoned expanses of Scotland‚Äôs wildest terrain, ancient footpaths chart a nearly forgotten history: Hundreds of mourners trudging from coasts and valleys, shouldering corpses in caskets for many miles. Over tall mountains, through rivers and woodlands, never letting the body touch the ground. Steeped in premonitions and superstition, these treks were a rural culture‚Äôs oldest death rites. Now, they‚Äôre some of the most unique hikes you can take.
Corpse, or coffin roads, were used throughout the Scotti‚Ä¶

entry.title: 5 of the best new cookbooks for summer
entry.summary: Dalmatia: Recipes from Croatia's Mediterranean Coast by Ino Kuvaƒçiƒá; Sama Sama by Julie Lin; Peach Street to Lobster Lane by Felicity Cloake; Smoke and Seasoned Bread by Hasan Semay; Pakistan by Maryam Jillani. Explore century-old Pakistani dishes, the stories behind US specialities and Dalmatia's coastal cuisine with these five new cookbooks to enjoy for the season. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). With more than 3,600 miles of coastline, Croatia‚Äôs Dalmatia region is intrinsically tied to the sea. This is apparent in its cuisine, where fish and seafood plucked directly from the Adriatic reigns supreme, whether it‚Äôs delicately sweet and silky oysters or smoky grilled sea bream. Melbourne-based restaura‚Ä¶

entry.title: The astonishing superpowers of nature‚Äôs most unloved animals
entry.summary:
Found across every continent except Antarctica and Australia, vultures like the lappet-faced species have lived among humans for millennia. But because they feast on the remains of dead animals, they‚Äôve been saddled with a reputation for carrying disease. Quite the contrary: By devouring rotting flesh, these scavengers prevent the spread of pathogens that cause bubonic plague, anthrax, and other diseases. They even stop carrion from emitting tens of millions of metric tons of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere each year. We owe a lot to this feathered cleanup crew. From their odd appendages to their unsavory hygiene, certain animals suffer an image problem. But their awkward attributes can be their biggest advantages.
The vulture has to be¬†one of the most reviled creatures on Ear‚Ä¶

entry.title: MSG is making a comeback. Was it ever really that bad for you?
entry.summary:
Monosodium glutamate, or MSG, is a common ingredient across Asian cuisines. But its history is riddled with false health claims and misinformation. For years, advertising and media connected the ingredient to ‚ÄúChinese Restaurant Syndrome.‚Äù Here‚Äôs what led to the misconception‚Äîand how MSG is being reclaimed today.
MSG‚Äôs reputation has been on the mend for years. Once blamed for dubious health concerns like headaches, numbness, and chest pains, the ingredient now appears in cocktails, cookies, and influencer pantry tours with growing pride.
But MSG‚Äôs cultural redemption hasn‚Äôt happened in a vacuum. Ajinomoto‚Äîthe world‚Äôs largest producer of monosodium glutamate, or MSG‚Äîhas played a quiet but consistent role in reshaping how we think about the additive. And a wave of Asian America‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan a self-drive boat tour of Ireland's River Shannon
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Irish heartlands put the emerald in the Emerald Isle ‚Äî and the River Shannon, which flows from County Cavan to County Kerry, is its lifeblood. It takes its name from the Celtic goddess Sinann: legend tells that she lifted the cover of a forbidden well in the Cavan Mountains, causing a flood to burst forth. Her drowned life force ebbed into the river she‚Äôd made, creating flower-filled meadows, tousled islands and fertile fields.
Cruising has long been a wonderful way to explore the Shannon ‚Äî the longest river in Ireland ‚Äî but now there‚Äôs more reason than ever to try it as the river‚Äôs boat fleet has been converted to hydro-treated vegetable oil (HVO) fuel, cutting carbon emissions by 92%. And compared to the crow‚Ä¶

entry.title: Watch cockatoos figure out a water fountain
entry.summary: In suburban Sydney, sulphur-crested cockatoos (Cacatua galerita) previously figured out how to break into garbage bins and have now deciphered human water fountains.  Sulphur-crested cockatoos have previously mastered garbage bins. Now, it‚Äôs water fountains. Australia‚Äôs sulphur-crested cockatoos are bringing a new meaning to the term ‚Äúbird-brained,‚Äù one innovation at a time. A few years ago, it was opening garbage bins to find food, a practice birds across dozens of neighborhoods eventually adopted. But now, the social birds are lining up, waiting their turns, and drinking straight from water fountains in a Sydney park. And, according to researchers, it‚Äôs just the latest evidence of cockatoo ‚Äúculture.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese birds, they constantly surprise me,‚Äù says Barbara Klump,‚Ä¶

entry.title: How conservation icon David Attenborough holds onto hope
entry.summary:
For seven¬†decades, Sir David Attenborough has traversed the globe to document the kaleidoscopic diversity of Earth‚Äôs ecosystems. At the age of 99, he‚Äôs narrated so many television programs that his voice has become synonymous with the wonder of the natural world. But in his long career full of wild encounters, one memory still stands out.
In 1957, when Attenborough was in his 30s, he traveled to a shallow warmwater cay on Australia‚Äôs Great Barrier Reef, where, for the first time in his life, he donned scuba gear to examine corals up close. ‚ÄúIt was a sort of sensory overload,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe countless tiny fish swimming between coral branches; the differences between the different coral structures. It opened up for me a whole new appreciation of the intricacies of life in the ocean.‚Äù ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this supertiny crustacean makes life work
entry.summary: Kim Bernard, at left, is an expert on Antarctic krill, a species crucial to the health of the continent‚Äôs food chain. For a research expedition on the Schmidt Ocean Institute‚Äôs R.V. Falkor (too), she was joined by Rachel Kaplan, a colleague from Oregon State University. For the first time, Antarctic krill have been found on seafloor vents. One scientist is working to figure out what they are doing there. Reporting in this article is presented by the National Geographic Society in partnership with Rolex under the National Geographic and Rolex Perpetual Planet Ocean Expeditions.
